verses.text: Do not mistreat the poor, nor show contempt for those in need.
verses.comment: The importance of caring for the poor is strongly affirmed in both Old and New Testaments as an essential virtue. The verse echoes Proverbs and anticipates Christ’s teaching about service and mercy.
verses.sectionHeader: Compassion for the Poor and Oppressed

verses.text: Do not turn away your face from the poor, and do not ignore the needs of the afflicted.
verses.comment: The command not to ignore the poor recalls God’s desire that justice and mercy be lived out in concrete ways: to turn away would be to reject God’s image in the other.

verses.text: Do not cause suffering to those who are hungry, nor provoke the poor in their need.
verses.comment: The call here reflects the biblical principle of solidarity with the suffering, and a warning against exploiting those in distress.

verses.text: Do not grieve the heart of one in need, nor delay giving to the poor.
verses.comment: The biblical tradition repeatedly emphasizes immediate action to aid those in hardship, seeing it as fulfilling God’s will.

verses.text: Do not reject the plea of those in distress, nor turn your face away from the poor.
verses.comment: Showing compassion for the suffering is an imitation of God Himself, who does not turn His back on those who cry out.

verses.text: Do not show disdain for the supplications of the oppressed, nor ignore their tears.
verses.comment: God hears the cries of the oppressed; the warning here foreshadows Christ’s identification with the suffering.

verses.text: Be gentle with the orphan, and like a father to their mother.
verses.comment: Fulfilling this command is pure worship, as later affirmed in the apostolic tradition, where caring for orphans and widows is seen as true religion.

verses.text: Embrace the poor with compassion, and do not send away the weak with empty hands.
verses.comment: The text points to a practical, personal mercy—true love acts, not just feels.

verses.text: Rescue the oppressed from the oppressor, and do not be hesitant in giving a verdict.
verses.comment: This exhortation reflects ancient Israel’s judicial ideals (see Deut 24:17), urging just action and courage in defending the oppressed, a theme echoed throughout biblical wisdom literature.

verses.text: Be a father to orphans and respond to their mother as a husband would, so you will be regarded as a child of the Most High, and He will love you more than your own mother does.
verses.comment: God’s special love for those who care for orphans foreshadows the deep spiritual family formed by those united in faith.

verses.text: Wisdom raises her children and takes care of those who seek her.
verses.comment: Personified Wisdom, echoing Proverbs, is shown to nurture and guide, alluding to divine wisdom as motherly and nurturing.

verses.text: Whoever loves Wisdom loves life, and those who seek her will be filled with joy.
verses.comment: There is a deep link between Wisdom and participation in the fullness of God’s life—a spiritual joy promised to seekers.

verses.text: Those who hold her fast inherit honor, and wherever the Lord leads, He will bless them.
verses.comment: Pursuing Wisdom leads not only to personal honor but to divine blessing, resonating with Christ’s Beatitudes.

verses.text: Those who serve her will minister to the Holy One; and those who love her are loved by the Lord.
verses.comment: Serving divine Wisdom foreshadows serving God directly, pointing to a sacramental life of ministry as a means of being loved by the Lord.

verses.text: Whoever hears her will judge nations, and whoever pays attention to her will dwell securely.
verses.comment: Wisdom as the source of authority points to the apocalyptic promise of reigning with Christ, the just judge.

verses.text: If you trust in her, you will inherit her, and your descendants will possess her.
verses.comment: Wisdom is a spiritual inheritance, received in faith, and passed on across generations—a hint of ongoing tradition.

verses.text: At first, Wisdom walks with him by crooked ways, bringing fear and distress, and tests him with her discipline, until she can trust his soul.
verses.comment: The process of growing in Wisdom involves spiritual trials, paralleling the discipline of God’s children described in Hebrews.

verses.text: She will test him with her commandments, and gently discipline him; then return to him with straight paths and cheer him up.
verses.comment: Wisdom brings about spiritual maturation through discipline, leading one back to joy after testing.

verses.text: But if he turns away, she will abandon him, and deliver him to his own downfall.
verses.comment: There is a warning against rejecting Wisdom, echoing passages where God gives people over to their chosen path.

verses.text: Watch for the opportune time, and beware of evil, and do not be ashamed to be yourself.
verses.comment: Sirach commends prudence and integrity, warning not to compromise one’s character even when facing evil, paralleling the advice in Prov 4:23 on guarding one’s heart.

verses.text: For there is a shame that leads to sin, and there is a shame that is glory and favor.
verses.comment: Not all shame is destructive; virtuous shame deters sin while false shame leads away from God—Paul’s letters distinguish between worldly sorrow and godly humility (2 Cor 7:10-11).

verses.text: Do not show partiality, to your own harm, or deference, to your downfall.
verses.comment: Impartiality in judgment echoes the Torah’s command for fair treatment (Lev 19:15), warning that favoritism undermines justice and harms both others and oneself.

verses.text: Do not refrain from speaking at the proper moment, and do not hide your wisdom.
verses.comment: Wisdom must be spoken timely; silence in the face of truth or need is negligence, recalling Ecclesiastes 3:7, 'a time to keep silence and a time to speak.'

verses.text: For wisdom becomes known through speech, and education through the words of the tongue.
verses.comment: Speech reveals wisdom, with education imparted through dialogue—this wisdom tradition is affirmed in Proverbs 18:21, 'Death and life are in the power of the tongue.'

verses.text: Never speak against the truth, but be ashamed of your ignorance.
verses.comment: Upholding truth is essential; ignorance ought to humble us, aligning with John 8:32’s focus on truth’s liberating power.

verses.text: Do not be ashamed to confess your sins, nor strive against the current of a rushing stream.
verses.comment: Repeated for emphasis: Confession is key to spiritual healing, underlining the value of reconciliation with God.

verses.text: Do not bend to a fool, nor let the powerful intimidate you.
verses.comment: Refusal to compromise righteousness before the powerful aligns with apostolic example and strengthens faith’s resolve.

verses.text: Strive for the truth until death, and the Lord will fight for you.
verses.comment: A call to perseverance in truth, reminiscent of martyrdom and the promise of divine advocacy—even unto death.

verses.text: Do not be quick with your words, nor slow to act in need.
verses.comment: Echoes biblical wisdom on speech and action: prudence in word, and readiness in charity.

verses.text: Do not be like a lion in your home, nor oppressive with your servants.
verses.comment: This guidance on gentleness echoes apostolic instructions to masters and heads of households.

verses.text: Do not let your hand be stretched out to receive and closed when it is time to give.
verses.comment: Generosity is a mark of righteousness; the verse warns against selfishness, harmonizing with Proverbs 11:25, 'A generous person will prosper.'

sections.title: Compassion for the Poor and Oppressed
